Wellllâ€¦

My first day of work EVER as an OT was September 11, 2001. Not a particularly auspicious day. Or time period, in general.

We all got through that, and I found myself running a really successful, small private practice in California. Then 2008 came along like a nuclear meltdown.

One very affluent school district I contracted with lost 50% of their savings account because their money was invested with Bernie Madoff. And my private pay clients disappeared overnight.

I had to pull out my plans B, C, Dâ€¦you get the idea. It wasnâ€™t pretty, but I got through it. Again.

I eventually moved to South Carolina and took a job at a hospital-based clinic (the best pediatric therapy clinic in town) so I could figure out what I wanted to do. Within a year they were threatening to lay everyone off. Good times.

I realized if I wanted to be in control of my income I needed to have my own practice.

By the way, that clinic finally closed recently. The new hospital CEO decided they would â€œno longer carry the pediatric rehabilitation service lineâ€. All of my therapy friends got laid off at once. Over the holidays.

Jeez, thanks for harshing my mellow
